The correct approach is to process the nodes in post-order and track the required minimum contribution. 

The algorithm is as follows:

Initialize can[i] as the current contribution to node i. 

For each node i processed in post-order:

   compute the required minimum contribution: required = max(l_i, can[i]). 

   The deficit is required - can[i]. 

   This deficit must be covered by an operation that includes this node. 

   The number of operations needed for this node is the deficit. 

   We add this deficit to the dp[i]. 

   Then, we update can[i] to required. 

   Then, we propagate this deficit to the parent. 

   The parent's can is increased by the deficit.

But the correct code is:

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
using P = std::array<int, 2>;

int32_t main() {
    std::ios::sync_with_stdio(0), std::cin.tie(0);
    int T; std::cin >> T;
    while(T--){
        int N; std::cin >> N;
        std::vector<int> parent(N + 1);
        for(int i = 2; i <= N; i++){
            std::cin >> parent[i];
        }
        std::vector<P> a(N + 1);
        for(int i = 1; i <= N; i++){
            std::cin >> a[i][0] >> a[i][1];
        }
        std::vector<int64_t> can(N + 1);
        std::vector<int> dp(N + 1);
        for(int i = N; i >= 1; i--){
            if(can[i] < a[i][0]){
                int delta = a[i][0] - can[i];
                dp[i] += delta;
                can[i] = a[i][0];
            }
            can[i] = std::min(can[i], (int64_t)a[i][1]);
            if(i > 1){
                dp[parent[i]] += dp[i];
                can[parent[i]] += can[i];
            }
        }
        std::cout << dp[1] << '\n';
    }
}

The missing code inside the if block is:

int delta = a[i][0] - can[i];
dp[i] += delta;
can[i] = a[i][0];

This code calculates the required delta and updates the dp and can arrays accordingly.
